The state of California is too large and diverse to have a defining sound. But say that something sounds like California rock circa the 1960s or early 70s
column2: and people have a pretty good idea what you're talking about. The Golden State band Golden Animals mine that particular epoch of mild psych and blues rock-- especially the middle part

column4: the duo's solid enough debut. What possessed guitarist Tommy Eisner (originally from Baltimore) and drummer Linda Beecroft (from Sweden) to specifically aim for the Doors above all else could well be a mix of laziness and audacity. Yet the music here is really-- to paraphrase Robert Christgau tackling the Cult aping Led Zeppelin-- the Doors simplified
column5:
with the band hitting all the major beats but falling short of anything cosmic.

Whether this is by design or default is up for debate
column6: but it does allow the group to skirt some of the many pitfalls that felled the Doors. In 2009
column7: several of Jim Morrison's most glaring pretensions have been diffused by decades of parody (and this heaped upon his own tragic tendency toward self-parody); his moan remains a sort of shorthand for the milieu that countless bands-- cool and lame alike-- have mimicked or mocked. Where Eisner falls on the sincerity scale is anyone's guess

as if he realizes the band is essentially a big goof and he's relishing the retread experience.

You can't turn back time

column1: It also helps that Eisner and Beecroft pilfer 60s signifiers but avoid borrowing some of the time's hoarier freak-out clichés. Indeed
column2: if the Doors are reference no. 1
column3: no. 2 are any number of blues-rock bands who knew that the power of a good searing lead or slide guitar trumps wacky hallucinogenic gimmicks any day.  The mojo the pair capture on even a short track like ""Alice"" is impressive

""Safe for the Time Being""

column3: Olly Oxen Free
column4: begins slightly out of focus-- not jarringly so
column5: but just bleary and blurry enough to catch your attention as your ears try to orient themselves. A synth wobbles. A bass drum rumbles. A voice (or sample of a voice) warbles along. A reverb-drenched guitar arpeggio vies with a fuzzy bass to give the track direction
column6: which singer Jonathan Visger refuses to provide with his yelpy and uneasy vocal melody. ""Fog""
column7: the first song on the album
column8: is stately and more subdued
column9: less amorphous. The drums plod at an uncommitted trot
column10: the guitars occasionally lock into something more forceful. The elusive vocals and airy keyboards meet somewhere in the ether
column11:
mysterious and majestic yet modest all the same.

These tracks are striking and spooky bookends to a disc that swings both ways. One moment it plays it safe with the relatively straight indie rock of ""Point A to Point B"" or the fitfully funky ""Only a Moment""
column12: and then it becomes loose and abstract on ""In the Mirror"" or the consciously unbalanced ""Downpour"" (sort of indie-rock screwed and chopped). Surely the all-encompassing shadow of Radiohead falls on this record
column13:
but it's equally reminiscent of the hazy art-rock of TV on the Radio (with whom ""Olly Oxen Free"" shares producer/engineer Chris Coady). Certainly a track like ""Alone"" makes the band sound like it's dined a few times at the Cookie Mountain Buffet.

Of course
column14: the Ypsilanti
column15: Mich.
column16: group isn't a match for those aforementioned acts
column17: at least not yet
column18: but they do demonstrate a similar ability to make weirdness seem normal
column19: and normal seem weird. Witness ""In the Mirror""
column20: which begins mournful but slowly evolves into something uneasier
column21: or ""Out Dragging the River""
column22: a simple slow-jam that gradually but only very subtly ups the energy of the skeletal arrangement
column23: like clouds gently parting to reveal the sun peeking out.

column1: Compared to songs such as these
column2: the propulsive ""Shiny"" and the angular ""Only a Moment"" at first seem conspicuously conventional
column3: but even these tracks go some strange places that save them from a more mundane fate. Yet one of the strengths of the disc is that its many eccentricities don't come off as cloying
column4: look-at-me affectations. Rather
column5: both band and album alike seem genuinely interested in keeping the sonic see-saw teetering
column6: never fully touching ground at either end
column7:
preferring to straddle the constantly unsteady fulcrum in between.

Any attempt to offer an authoritative overview of the Kinks' career is fraught with difficulty. During the band's long run from 1962 through 1996
column2: the Davies brothers and their abettors never morphed into a nostalgia act
column3: continually changing and writing new material to create a varied but distinctive body of work. The variation isn't only stylistic
column4: either-- their catalog varies a lot in quality as well. The Kinks' work from 1966 through 1970 is basically unimpeachable
column5: but opinions differ widely on what came after
column6: and for good reason. So in constructing a six-disc look at the band's vast catalog
column7:
the challenge becomes to adequately represent each of the its phases while balancing considerations of what's actually worthwhile.

Picture Book answers this challenge through a capricious
column8: sometimes puzzling track selection
column9: which was assisted by Ray Davies. It's a (mostly) chronological jumble of singles
column10: album tracks
column11: alternate mixes
column12: mono versions
column13: live cuts
column14: rarities
column15: hits
column16: misses
column17: and even a couple demos and one rehearsal. Two-thirds of the material is familiar album and single tracks
column18: though
column19: meaning that hardcore fans hoping for a bonanza will ultimately find about two discs worth of stuff they don't have or previously found difficult to get
column20:
some of which are hard-to-distinguish mono mixes. Then there's the matter of who actually wants a box that covers the band's whole career but leaves out tons of the band's best tracks and has a sixth disc that's mostly awful.

The set starts with BBC announcer Brian Matthew introducing the band before ""You Really Got Me"" rips into rock'n'roll and takes out a lasting bite with its brutal slashed-amp distortion and stupid-simple riff. The 1964 song put the band firmly on the map-- it was a UK #1 and a Top Ten hit in the U.S.-- but it was actually their third single. Here
column21: it's followed a few tracks later by their first
column22: a cover of ""Long Tall Sally"" that justifiably went nowhere. Omitted is their second single
column23: the superb and infectiously melodic flop ""You Still Want Me""
column24: which was thankfully included on Essential's 1998 remaster of the band's self-titled debut.

column1: The period from 1964 through 1971 covers the first three discs and spills onto the fourth
column2: which is as good an assessment as any of the band's best and most creative period. The run of albums from 1966's Face to Face through Something Else and Village Green Preservation Society to 1969's Arthur
column3: or the Decline And Fall of the British Empire is a spectacular four-LP run that established Ray Davies as one of the keenest observers of British society and cemented the band's influence and legacy. It's hard to go wrong skipping around the first few discs of this set
column4: though the rough demo of ""Dead End Street"" and the twice-aborted rehearsal of ""Come on Now"" are poor substitutes for the familiar versions.

column1: A host of non-album tracks make this section particularly rewarding. ""Autumn Almanac"" is practically a blueprint for XTC
column2: the radio session version of Dave Davies' overlooked and excellent ""Love Me Till the Sun Shines"" burns with sharp intensity
column3: Dutch B-side ""This Is Where I Belong"" was justly included on Kink Kronikles and sounds no less vital here
column4: and the haunting piano-and-vocal cast-off ""I Go to Sleep"" is simply gorgeous. Early outtakes ""A Little Bit of Sunlight"" and ""This I Know"" also hit the British Invasion sweet spot. It's a crime that the band was kept out of the U.S. by an American Federation of Musicians ban during its most creative period
column5: but the band became so quintessentially English during that period that it's possible American audiences wouldn't have been receptive anyway.

column1: The Kinks' golden era extended into the 70s with the Lola Vs Powerman & the Moneygoround and Muswell Hillbillies LPs
column2: which are amply represented. It's also nice to hear three tracks from the soundtrack to the comedy Percy
column3: which has long been treated like a bastard child in the band's discography. ""The Way Love Used to Be"" is an especially great song
column4: a dark
column5: moody ballad sweetened by lush orchestration. The Muswell album found Ray Davies taking a break from incisively and sympathetically critiquing British society to instead indulge a little second-hand Americana. Bassist Peter Quaife had exited the band in 1969
column6: and the Davies brothers and drummer Mick Avory had expanded the band to include a full-time keyboardist-- John Gosling's warm Hammond organ and tack piano deepened the Americanness of songs like ""Muswell Hillbilly"" and ""20th Century Man"". ""Alcohol""
column7: presented here in a live version
column8: echoes some of the music hall traditions that would become the band's staple reference point in the mid-70s.

column1: During the Kinks' time at RCA in the 70s
column2: Ray Davies indulged in a series of poorly received concept albums that don't wear nearly as well today as the band's 60s output
column3: but there are quite a few gems hidden away in this period
column4: which comprises the bulk of Disc Four. The two-part would-be rock opera Preservation had an endearingly rough sound (it was some of the first material recorded at the band's own Konk studios)
column5: but the inclusion of female backing vocalists and a horn section in the band didn't always add much to the songs. The other two albums from this period
column6: Soap Opera and Schoolboys in Disgrace
column7: a sequel to Preservation that focused on the villain
column8: Mr. Flash
column9: are scantly represented with three total tracks
column10: but the choices are inspired: Soap Opera's ""Holiday Romance"" is a wonderful music hall throwback with hints of Noel Coward
column11: while the loan Schoolboys track
column12: ""No More Looking Back""
column13: is a cinematic preview of 90s Britpop
column14: from Dave's harmonized lead guitar intro to Ray's perceptive lyrics about the way people who've left us linger in strange ways. If this set were more interested in telling the story of the band
column15: it probably would have also included ""The Hard Way""
column16: a heavy track that anticipated the band's late-70s shift to slick hard rock and became a concert staple.

column1: The band's six hard rock albums for Arista
column2: released from 1977 through 1984
column3: represent their most misunderstood period. Some fans of the band's 60s output dismiss it entirely
column4: and it's certainly not up to that standard
column5: but very little is. They experienced their biggest success in the U.S. during this period (1979's Low Budget
column6: at #11
column7: was their highest-charting US album)
column8: and they were at the peak of their concert drawing power
column9: touring almost constantly back and forth across the Atlantic. Oddly
column10: they were making corporate rock just as their old music returned to vogue as inspiration for British punks
column11: with the Jam covering ""David Watts"". There is a fair amount of good stuff on these albums
column12: but you have to dig more for it
column13: and not all of it is here. The two biggest omissions are ""Juke Box Music"" and ""Around the Dial""
column14: which is sort of an old crank's companion to Elvis Costello's ""Radio Radio"".

column1: Some of what has been included just misses the mark. Low Budget in particular is crammed with lame songs like ""Attitude""
column2: a terrible diatribe that's the exact opposite of the empathetic
column3: detailed storytelling Ray Davies excels at. Even some of the better songs from this period
column4: like the slow character study ""Rock and Roll Fantasy""
column5: lack the wit and insight of ""Two Sisters"" and ""Sunny Afternoon"". ""Destroyer""
column6: though
column7: is a slaying
column8: rambunctious rock track that revisits Ray's encounter with Lola the next day to hilarious effect. The band is also effective on ""Sleepwalker"" and ""Misfits""
column9: nicely summing up modern alienation on the latter with the line ""Take a real good look around. The misfits are everywhere."" The relative rarities form this period are mostly lackluster. The ebulliently nostalgic storytelling of ""Come Dancing"" is here as a weak demo
column10: while ""Maybe I Love You"" is an inconsequential nothing from the scrap heap. ""Nuclear Love"" is an enjoyable excursion into near-New Wave but hardly essential.

column1: As the band's Arista deal wrapped up with Word of Mouth in 1984
column2: they were already falling back out of commercial favor (they'd never really returned to it in the UK)
column3: and long-simmering tension between Dave Davies and Mick Avory led to the drummer's exit
column4: much to Ray's dismay. Most of Disc Six is given to the post-Avory era
column5: when the band wandered in the commercial wilderness
column6: recording weak hard rock albums that are scarcely worth summarizing with a track or two
column7: much less hearing in their entirety. The studio leftover ""Million Pound Semi-Detached"" is the most charming thing from that period included here
column8: in part because it sounds like it was recorded at Konk in the mid-70s
column9: but also because Ray's wit has returned in its tale of a couple buying a house
column10: raising a family
column11: and generally living the dream
column12: only to find that the dream left out all the boredom and frustration. It was their best comment on the State of British Life since Dave's post-Empire lament ""Living on a Thin Line""

column1: The set wraps up with the final Kinks material
column2: from 1993's Phobia and their last record
column3: the hodgepodge To the Bone. Bizarrely
column4: there are five songs from Phobia
column5: and not one of them is ""Hatred (A Duet)""
column6: the only truly great Kinks song from the band's final decade together. That song features Dave and Ray satirizing their own famously stormy working relationship
column7: but the songs here don't even approach that level of humor or humanity. It's little wonder that hardly anyone noticed when the band split in 1996.

column1: Perhaps the ultimate drawback of covering the Kinks' entire oeuvre on one set is the need to tack on songs from their most irrelevant records. It's difficult to discern precisely who the audience for this set is-- the band's hardcore fans will appreciate most of the rarities
column2: but this is not a catch-all for Kinks odds and sods
column3: and the sheer volume of material that any true fan already owns means that the set is a pricey way to get what rarities there are. If you're new to the band and absolutely require a career overview before going straight to the essential late-60s albums
column4: Castle's Ultimate Collection
column5: which covers up to 1984
column6:
is a much more solid introduction.

Received wisdom states that jungle brought about its own demise with its over-hasty coffee table gentrification (as symbolized by replacement genre name ""drum'n'bass"")
column2: ushering in muso jazz and studio musicianship while draining the dancefloor energy that made the music vital in the first place. Of course
column3: with drum'n'bass having spent more than a decade pounding ""dancefloor energy"" into an ideas-devoid mono-groove
column4: it's worth examining whether the prior phase of decadent gentrification was really all its detractors claim it to be. Listening to Goldie's bloated 2xCD debut Timeless again
column5: what irritates isn't the presence of noodling saxophones so much as the suspicion that Goldie thought it took a saxophone to make jungle epic. Orbital
column6: with the clear vision sometimes gifted to outsiders
column7: proved on their 1994 faux-jungle stab ""Are We Here?"" that the real possibility of the ""epic"" in jungle was hidden within the beat programming
column8: offering up a broiling sea of slithering
column9:
snake-like drums.

I like to think Orbital had been listening to A Guy Called Gerald (aka Gerald Simpson)
column10: who a year later released perhaps the only drum'n'bass album to successfully match gentrification with a consistent focus on ""rhythmic danger."" It's this
column11: together with the album's scarcity
column12: that has long made Black Secret Technology a much-touted candidate for ""best jungle album ever."" Previously
column13: though
column14: listeners had to imagine an ideal version of this music
column15: squinting their ears to hear past the (diametrically flawed) murkiness or limp politeness of the mastering on the album's two prior releases. Thankfully
column16: this new remaster of the original 1995 release achieves the best of both worlds
column17:
capturing the density of the original productions with a sharpness and force that was hitherto missing. 

Perhaps the greatest achievement of Black Secret Technology was to break so radically with many of his peers' presumption of an inverse relationship between rhythmic complexity and musical sophistication. Blending in with the class of 95's aspirational mood-- albeit offering a more minimalist
column18: Detroit-inspired take on it-- Gerald laces his productions with soft-centred synth pads
column19: slightly moody soulful diva soundbites
column20: precariously wafting flute samples
column21: and eerie strings. But all this remains a foil for the unrepentant
column22: rumbling boom of the bass-- and especially the beats. There is simply no other single-artist jungle album that pushes consciousness-altering beat programming as far
column23: as fearlessly
column24:
as it is pushed here. 

Indeed
column25: when it comes to rhythms this album is an embarrassment of riches. ""The Reno"" features cyborg drummers that seem to multiply before your eyes (or ears)
column26: the rhythm doubling over itself again and again while a diva cries ""eeeh yeah-eh-eh-eh
column27: all swirling with a viscosity reminiscent of DJ Pierre's ""Wild Pitch"" house sound. On ""Survival""
column28: chattering time-stretched snares are progressively shattered into smaller and smaller pieces
column29: until the groove resembles a fractured Cubist portrait of itself. On ""Dreaming of You""
column30: snippets of hand-percussion seem to rise and curl around your eardrums like steam. Most amazingly
column31: the ravished and ravishing ""Cyberjazz"" is possessed with convulsive shudders
column32:
beats fluttering with a stop-start nervous intensity that evokes a myriad of electric synapses flickering on and off. 

Gerald's approach to rhythm is almost decadent at times: frequently
column33: painstakingly assembled interlocking layers of beats are placed almost on the edge of conscious awareness
column34: or otherwise punchy rhythms become swallowed up in tidal swells of infra-red bass. On gorgeous reggae-jungle single ""Finley's Rainbow"" the astonishing
column35: counter-intuitive beats rain down with murderous fury somewhere far off in the distance; the effect is like watching a thunderstorm over a distant bay
column36: with only brief moments of being lashed by the hail and the lightning. At times this can be slightly frustrating; at others I'm reminded of that strange combination of harmony and headwreck that krautrockers Can concocted on Future Days (ironically or fittingly
column37:
Gerald's greatest ever attempt to toughen up his mindboggling mid-nineties aesthetic remains his remix of Can's ""Tango Whiskeyman""). 

Like Can
column38: Gerald understood that the division between ""head music"" and ""body music"" is false and unnecessary: Black Secret Technology achieves its sense of hypnotic drift through panoramic rhythmic compulsion
column39:
supplying a frictionless endorphin high that only comes with a massive expense of physical energy. Gentrification? More like a very noble savagery.

column2: they had hits with secular and nonsecular songs alike
column3: which cemented their legacy as one of country's most conflicted acts: On guitar
column4: Charlie was sensible and earnest
column5: but Ira
column6: playing mandolin
column7: was temperamental and worldly. The brothers' differences illuminate the morals in every song
column8: whether it's a churchly number like ""The Family Who Prays"" or a grisly narrative like ""Knoxville Girl"". Ira died in a car crash in 1965; Charlie continues to make music
column9:
but has no one to harmonize with him.

After his strong self-titled comeback in 2007
column10: the 81-year-old Louvin has released two follow-ups
column11: each exploring a starkly different theme. Steps to Heaven is an uplifting collection of old hymns; Charlie Louvin Sings Murder Ballads and Disaster Songs is pretty self-explanatory. One is about glory and redemption
column12: the other tragedy and tribulation. While he's not nearly as vocally agile as he was decades ago
column13: he does sound better-- stronger
column14: clearer-- than he did on last year's Charlie Louvin. On Steps to Heaven
column15: he sounds plucky and rejuvenated
column16: tearing into these ten hymns with spirited reverence and hitting even the high notes confidently and happily. Producer Mark Nevers (best known for his work with Lambchop) sets him in a casual church service setting
column17:
backed primarily by Lee Derrick's rollicking piano and a bold backing choir that occasionally intrudes on Louvin's leads. His lively ""There's a Higher Power"" and intensely testimonial ""I Am Bound for the Promised Land"" are sincerely moving. He conveys belief and contentment with every note.

Steps to Heaven may be the more spiritually rewarding of these two albums
column18: but Murder Ballads is much more fun. These grim accounts of mine collapses
column19: shootings
column20: train wrecks
column21: and dead babies-- some of which appeared on the Louvin Brothers' 1956 album
column22: Tragic Songs of Life-- have an almost tabloid aplomb in their matter-of-fact details. Louvin sounds spry on opener ""Darling Corey"" (featuring Andrew Bird on fiddle) and ""Dixie Boll Weevil""
column23: on which he voices both the farmer and the destructive beetle. Most of the album
column24: however
column25: is much more somber and often elegant
column26: with Louvin relating these stories with an easy
column27: earthy gravity
column28: as if he's singing about people he has known personally. ""The Little Grave in Georgia"" sets the mournful story of a dead teenager against a soft two-step

column33:
like the conductor scalded to death by a steam engine on ""Wreck of the Old 97"". What a way to go.

Of course
column34: there is some thematic and musical overlap between these two releases. Steps to Heaven
column35: as its title makes clear

column40:
""The hand of God was in it all.""

With the exception of 808 State-- whose 1989 ""Pacific"" was the last important single the label released-- little of the post-Morley material here is memorable. Morley's gradual estrangement from ZTT was more a symptom of its shifting priorities than a cause

The Iraq War is a cataract in our understanding of the nation of Iraq and its modern history. It clouds the way we view and think about the country to the extent that we in the United States are blinded to anything beyond the violence of the last few years and the atrocities of the Saddam Hussein era. The obscuring effect of recent events leads me to believe that Honest Jon's Give Me Love might be the most important archival compilation of the year. Outside of a very small number of performers
column2: including oudist Munir Bashir and jazz musician Amir ElSaffar
column3: very little Iraqi music has ever made an impact internationally. Indeed
column4:
for most of the 20th century the popular music of Iraq and most of the rest of the Arab world lived completely within the shadow of Lebanese and especially Egyptian artists.

This compilation
column5: then
column6: represents one of a precious few attempts to provide a clear window into the cultural life of a widely misunderstood place-- the Iraq of the late 1920s
column7: during a period of British hegemony in the region that began when the Ottomans were driven out of Mesopotamia during the First World War. The Gramophone Company and its subsidiary His Master's Voice-- HMV today-- were the first major companies to make recordings in 1925. (In the pursuit of record buyers' money the world over
column8: Gramophone unwittingly provided one of the greatest cultural services of the 20th century by sending its recording engineers across the globe to document local musics-- I'd give a lot to be allowed several weeks in a hypothetical Gramophone vault.) Others quickly followed
column9: including Polyphone
column10: Baidaphon
column11: Odeon
column12: and Columbia
column13: but all the recordings included here are drawn from HMV's nearly 900 78 rpm sides
column14:
all made from 1925 to 1929.

When approaching this compilation
column15: it's important to remember something that's true of records from all eras: the recording medium is a part of the music. In today's studio
column16: you might have 64 tracks
column17: 20 different kinds of microphones
column18: and an infinite amount of extra gear your can pile onto a record. Then
column19: they had a mechanical recording device with a horn that the musicians had to be carefully arranged around to get the right mix of sounds. The dawn of electrical recording was right around 1925; by 1926
column20: it was the norm in most of the world. But the liners here state pretty plainly that most of these records were made without microphones
column21: and I frankly don't know enough of the difference to argue the point. What I can tell you is that this disc is nearly devoid of the surface crackle of 78s
column22: and the sound is very clear. But one shouldn't expect a modern range of frequency response
column23: as the low-end of performances rarely registered well on 1920s recordings.

column1: What you will hear are impassioned performances
column2: instrumental and vocal
column3: from some of the most well-regarded performers in Baghdad of the era. Most of them are Jewish-- for various reasons
column4: Iraq's religious minorities dominated the country's music prior to the 1950s
column5: when the vast majority of Christians and essentially all the Jews fled. This exodus began during World War II after a pro-Nazi coup d'etat and subsequent pogrom. Audiences were split by gender-- public performances for men by women were looked down upon
column6: and many
column7: though not all
column8: female singers were recruited from brothels
column9: which was another barrier to respect. The few recordings by women included here have same melismatic fire as their male counterparts
column10: though
column11: and nearly every track has the characteristic Iraqi slowness that makes the country's music distinct in spite of obvious Egyptian
column12: Persian
column13: and Indian influences. The other caution for modern listeners is not to expect the kind of hook-filled instant gratification we're used to today-- this is music you need to soak in and feel
column14: from the aching love songs to the frenetic instrumental taqsims.

column1: The ornamental vocals mask often straightforward lyrics
column2: which translate to phrases such as ""I wait for my lover on tenterhooks
column3: ""Since you left me my eyes are on the brink of shutting down for good
column4: and ""Short of dying
column5: how can I get you out of mind?"" Songs of the brokenhearted indeed. The instrumentation consists of small ensembles
column6: with violin
column7: oud (an Arabic lute played with a fluttering
column8: staccato technique)
column9: mutbij (a wooden double flute with a wailing
column10: nasal tone)
column11: qanun (a type of zither) and hand percussion. Some songs include small choirs positioned far from the horn. This was an urban type of arrangement
column12: and many rural songs were transposed to these ensembles for recording purposes-- it's important to note that these weren't field recordings

this is a compelling peek at the soul of Iraq that's been so long obscured to us by the fog of war.
